dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so get this, they're sending rockets to the moon... after the FDA approves it!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so get this, they're sending rockets to the moon... after the F D A approves it!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Part of our long-term vision is one day 3D-printing rockets and infrastructure on Mars, he says.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Whoa, wait, no, no, that, uh, the FDA part was totally a joke in the article. Like, obviously.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Whoa, wait, no, no, that, uh, the F D A part was totally a joke in the article. Like, obviously.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The ground truth article does not contain the term 'FDA'.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, right, right! My bad! But the moon part, though, still!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, right, right! My bad! But the moon part, though, still!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Part of our long-term vision is one day 3D-printing rockets and infrastructure on Mars, he says.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, Relativity Space! This is wild. Totally 3D-printed rockets, you know? The Terran 1.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, Relativity Space! This is wild. Totally 3D-printed rockets, you know? The Terran one.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Space Relativity founders Tim Ellis and Jordan Noone examine the second stage of their Terran 1 rocket, which was entirely 3D-printed

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yes, exactly! The whole thing. And, uh, a billion-dollar company now, a unicorn already!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yes, exactly! The whole thing. And, uh, a billion-dollar company now, a unicorn already!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The $140 million fundraise brings the total amount of investment in the company to $185 million.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Unicorn status! And Mark Cuban, their first investor! Elon Musk even, like, praised them.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Unicorn status! And Mark Cuban, their first investor! Elon Musk even, like, praised them.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Los Angeles-based startup has a lot of believers, including billionaire Mark Cuban, the companys first investor and also a participant in the current round... [The article does not mention Elon Musk].

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yes, exactly! And it's all about that manufacturing, right? The 3D printing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yes, exactly! And it's all about that manufacturing, right? The 3D printing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Relativitys Ellis believes that its competitive advantage lies in its manufacturing process. The company is 3D-printing its rockets, from the engine to the structure...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. Those massive Stargate printers. That's their competitive edge, um, for sure.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. Those massive Stargate printers. That's their competitive edge, um, for sure.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To that end, the company has built four large 3D-printers, which it calls Stargate, at its manufacturing facility.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And the speed! They can, like, iterate rockets so quickly once the factory's up!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the speed! They can, like, iterate rockets so quickly once the factory's up!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Once engineering is complete and the factory is fully built, Ellis says, his company will be able to produce and iterate rockets very quickly.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Which is insane, because, uh, there are over a hundred small rocket startups!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is insane, because, uh, there are over a hundred small rocket startups!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: There are over 100 startups now in the race to build small rockets, which are made for smaller satellites that have become increasingly popular...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But only one, um, has actually launched commercial payloads to orbit, Rocket Lab.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But only one, um, has actually launched commercial payloads to orbit, Rocket Lab.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: However, only one of those companiesthe L.A.-based Rocket Labhas launched commercial payloads to orbit.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, but Relativity already has customers! Telesat, mu Space. Even, like, Amazon whispers!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, but Relativity already has customers! Telesat, mu Space. Even, like, Amazon whispers!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The company has signed deals with Canadian communications company Telesat to deliver internet satellites to orbit, with Thai company mu Space, and with Spaceflight... [The article does not mention Amazon].

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And they're already talking about Mars! Printing rockets on Mars eventually.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And they're already talking about Mars! Printing rockets on Mars eventually.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Part of our long-term vision is one day 3D-printing rockets and infrastructure on Mars, he says.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yes, exactly! Not just launching to Mars, but like, building there. That's the vision!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yes, exactly! Not just launching to Mars, but like, building there. That's the vision!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Part of our long-term vision is one day 3D-printing rockets and infrastructure on Mars, he says.
